msItem.title: Compilation of Henry, of Huntingdon, 1084?–1155: Historia anglorum and Roger, of Hoveden, -approximately 1201: Chronica [Latin]
msItem.rubric: Fol. 1r. Incipit prologus hystorie anglorum contexte ab henrico archidiacono huntindon' ad alexandrum lincolniensem episcopum Anno domini .m.c.xlv.
msItem.incipit: Cum in omni fere litterarum studio
msItem.explicit: Fol. 1v. aspice quam nichili sit honor lux gloria mundi.
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit prologus ad alexandrum lincolniensem episcopum directum.
msItem.rubric: Fol. 2r. Hystorie anglorum liber primus incipit. De regno Romanorum in Britannia. Britannia
msItem.explicit: Fol. 29v. suscepto periurus merito regi uictoriam cessit.
msItem.rubric: Fol. 29v. Historia saxonum uel anglorum post obitum Bede [remainder erased and replaced in hand of s. xviiin (see below) by by siue Annalium Rogeri de Houeden Pars prior]
msItem.incipit: In exordio huius operis genealogiam regum nordhumbrorum
msItem.explicit: Fol. 108vb/30. maxima uenerat ex anglia. M.C. xlviij. Anno xiiij Henrici suo nepoti dauid

Fol. 112ra/27. caro sum [four words erased and replaced in hand of s. xviiin (see below) by Pars prior Annalium Rogeri de Houeden.] Explicit cronica mariani scoti de gestis regum anglorum usque ad obitum regis Stephani et inicium regni Henrici secundi qui fuit filius imperatricis et Galfridi plantagen' comitis andegauie [all after first word deleted and, with caret to indicate it, replaced by the newly inserted Pars prior].
msItem.note: Not the true text of Henry of Huntingdon but a compilation.

listBibl.bibl: In addition to the introductions of Arnold and Stubbs see Diana Greenway, Henry of Huntingdon (MS 31 above), cxxxvii—cxxxviii, where this is MS Oa.

supportDesc.support:
Written on 114 membrane leaves of rather poor quality with many blemishes patched before writing, preceded by one membrane flyleaf.
Foreleaf: fol.ir, contents-list; fol. iv, number, contents-list.
supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in ink (s. xvii or s. xviii).
supportDesc.collation: Collation: 1-148 152. Catchwords, not by the scribe(s) of the text, are on the last pages of all quires except the last. Quire numbers, roman figures of medium size, are in the centre of the lower margins of quires 1-13. At the bottom of the first four leaves of quires 1-14 are the remains of a series of quire signatures a-o plus roman figures in a cursive hand of s. xivin.

layoutDesc.layout:
Written in two columns, each
175-80 55-60
31-2 lines. Pricked in outer margins and for verticals. Ruled in crayon. Folding is HSOS.

handDesc.handNote: Protogothic bookhand by several scribes, a good hand to about fol. 37 but thereafter becoming less formal and from about fol. 64 onwards of a much more documentary type. Punctuation is by low point.

decoDesc.decoNote: A six-line initial brown and white C with green and brown infilling is at the beginning of the prologue, fol. 1r and a similar ten-line B with a white interlace pattern on the shaft is at the beginning of the text, fol. 2r.
On fol. 15v is a five/six-line brown T with a white interlace pattern on its stem.
On fol. 103r, opposite STANDARD in the account of the Battle of the Standard, is a drawing of a standard on a long pole on a four-wheeled carriage. Alexander and Temple, no. 72.

binding.p: Sewn on five bands between millboards covered with an Oxford binding of blind-tooled leather, s. xviii2, rebacked, as on MS 197 and similar to those on MSS 34 and 39. Inside the back cover is a typed description of the book when it was sent for repair and of the action taken, by James Brockman, December 1989. A fragment of the old spine is mounted inside the back cover.

history.provenance:
The medieval history of the manuscript is unknown but marginalia in English hands of ss. xiii—xvi show that it was used over a long period. It was later in the possession of Sir Simonds D'Ewes (d. 1650), for whose library see A. G. Watson, The Library of Sir Simonds D'Ewes (London, 1966). Evidence of his ownership is 49: at the top centre of fol. 1r, written over an erasure; for an illustration of such a number see Watson, pl. V and for a concordance of the numbers and the manuscripts which bear them (in which 49 is untraced) see ibid. 344. D'Ewes's hand (for which see Watson, pls. II, III, and VII) appears in three places; see above. The book should have gone to the Harleian Library in 1706 (for Humfrey Wanley's negotiations for the purchase see Watson, 56-61) but may have been out of the D'Ewes family's hands by then or temporarily on loan and all that can be deduced about it is that it was in a collection with other manuscripts; it was acquired by the College from an unknown source in 1768 along with MSS 34, 35, and perhaps 39, with all of which it shares a number of features (see under MS 35, citing Library Committee Book 1, meeting of 30 December 1768).
Pre-All Souls marks are a.2o, 9.L.5, and 231 (s. xvii or xviii) on the front pastedown, and a contents-note and a reference to William Nicolson's Historical Library, evidently the London, 1736 edition, on fol. ir as in MSS 34, 35, and 39. On fol. iv is 14:3 and, in different ink, two titles (s. xviiiin).
All Souls library identifications, on which see Introduction, are, on the front pastedown, vv.9.6 and vv.3.6 (both deleted), MS. 36 (figure added), 85 (pencil), and bookplate no. 9, with L.R.1.f.6 written on it.

recordHist.source: Andrew G. Watson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts of All Souls College Oxford (Oxford, 1997)

availability.p: For enquiries relating to this manuscript please contact library@all-souls.ox.ac.uk.
